reporting-org.narrative: UTZ - joined forces with Rainforest Alliance

title.narrative: Building capacities for sector change: Global program

description.narrative: In 2020 we will have strengthened the lobby and advocacy capacity of civil society organizations in Indonesia, Central America, Kenya, Uganda, Cote d'Ivoire, Ghana and Malawi. As a result we will see an improvement of policy environment (both government and companies) and support services in these countries related to one or more priority themes. On the global level, we will influence the agenda, discourse and policies of International sector platforms and companies related to these themes. These themes are: 1. Sustainable productivity Raising smallholder productivity in a sustainable way is a key component of sector transformation. It is needed to increase income of the farmer and increase production while lowering the environmental footprint. 2. Smallholder inclusion & farmer group strengthening The aim is to increase the inclusion of smallholders in supply-chain driven sustainability programs. Strengthening farmer organizations is seen as an important way to increase the bargaining power of smallholder farmers in the supply chain. 3. Women’s empowerment and gender The goal is to increase the inclusion of women in certification and access to benefits as well as to reduce discrimination and violence against women. 4. Climate and water The focus is on up scaling of best practices in smallholder adaptation to climate change and sustainable water use. 5. Child labor The focus is on prevention, monitoring and remediation of child labor. 6. Living wage The goal is to improve wages of workers on coffee and tea estates towards a living wage. Management and support of sector partnership program and implementation of global projects is done from the UTZ office in Amsterdam
SP-GLOB Building capacities for sector change: Global program

title.narrative: Ultimate Outcome 2: Policy changes & implementation

description.narrative: Policies are better in line with the needs of female and male farmers, smallholders and workers; Adequate implementation of policies;

title.narrative: DD1 # of ((inter)national) standards and policies implemented

description.narrative: Adequate implementation of policies

comment.narrative: 29-04-2019: Improved implementation of RA standard (deforestation, gender)
Target value for this period has not been defined yet.
29-04-2020: RA standard: no producers in protected areas, after more extensive collection of geolocation data, training of auditors etc.
29-04-2021: Gender training modules for training of RA staff and partners to improve implementation of RA standard

title.narrative: DD2 # of policy changes that UTZ /partners contributed to

description.narrative: Policies are better in line with the needs of (female) smallholders, (female) farmers and (female) farm workers, based on their needs and interests

comment.narrative: 29-04-2019: Improved new (draft) RA standard; improved policy on living wage (dutch MOFA; ILO)

29-04-2020: 1) RA policy towards social requirements; from zero tolerance to Assess and Adress The Assess and Address approach (as opposed to zero tollerance), is endorsed by the RA board (before only in pre-merger UTZ) and through the new standard scaled up to new sectors beyond cocoa (including tea, coffee, hazelnut). It is also applied to other criteria beyond CLMRS (e.g. forced labor, discrimination, workplace violence and harassment). 2) RA policy towards High Conservation Value Areas. The new Rainforest Alliance standard has a new approach to High Conservation Value areas, endorsed by the HCV Resource Network 3)The new RA standard has incorporated new gender criteria based on lessons learned in SP ; 4) RA Pesticides approach: RA added new pesticides to the list based on Pan UK report (SP Ghana program) 5) RA Chain of Custody: RA scales up shared investment in the supply chain through ChOC standard. 6) The governments of Cote d'Ivoire and Ghana have started the development of an African regional standard for cocoa, Q4 2019, which included some "risk based"approaches to tackle child labor in cocoa. 7) The gha / cdi govs used the Living Income benchmark to inform the LID -Living Income Differential ( it is not the same as the benchmark)

29-04-2021: Major Dutch Retailer has committed to implement the payment of a LW premium on top of market price for the next two years, reducing the gap to a living wage for farm workers. In phase III, the impact of the payment of higher wages would be investigated and documented for workers, their community, the farms and the retailer.

title.narrative: Pathway 2: Research and pilots to create evidence for L&A

description.narrative: Research and pilots with relevant stakeholders to create evidence and best practices to L&A for policy changes

these targets have been corrected to align with the new/additional reporting guidelines
17-04-2018: climate risks (CIAT), online coffee variety catalogue (WCR), online living wage toolkit (fairfood), Living inclome benchmark for Ghana (SFL)

29-04-2020: 1) strategic advice and commodity pricing analysis. 2) Risk Maps and Risk Assessment Tool for Child Labor, Forced Labor, discrimination, workplace harassment and violence 3) research on living income benchmark CdI & Ghana
these targets have been corrected to align with the new/additional reporting guidelines

title.narrative: Baseline Report

description.narrative: The baseline provides an elaborate context-analysis per country, containing details about capacity of partners and the current state regarding the thematic goals for L&A. The baseline focuses on three main areas: a. Description of baseline situation of context and stakeholders b. Baseline of outcomes of ToC c. Capacities assessment

title.narrative: # of baseline reports

comment.narrative: 1 baseline report for global is completed
10-01-2018: 1 baseline report for global completed

title.narrative: Pathway 1: UTZ engages in direct Lobby & Advocacy

description.narrative: UTZ engages in direct L&A, knowledge sharing, awareness raising and linking actors

title.narrative: DD3 # of issues brought forward by UTZ, partners and MSPs included in the agenda of public and private policy makers

description.narrative: Agenda setting

comment.narrative: tbu
29-04-2019: Living wage: (ILO; Dutch MOFA; Ahold )

29-04-2020: 1) we were able to influence the agenda of the Conference on the eradication of child labour in global supply chains, to share our practical experience on the ground, and establish new partnerships and interest in our approach beyond certification. 2) Amsterdam Declaration has put Cocoa prominently on its agenda (cocoa & deforestation). 3) GIZ focused on agroforestry in their annual conference and gave space for RA to showcase our approach 4) Sustainable Coffee Challenge an important multistakeholder platform, where we put deforestation in coffee higher on the agenda (together with CI)

29-04-2021: October 22nd, 2020, the European Parliament voted for a legislative initiative to stop EU-driven global deforestation through mandatory due diligence for companies placing products on the EU market

title.narrative: DD3 # of advocacy messages and evidence used in political statements, policies, plans/media items by stakeholders

description.narrative: Discursive change

comment.narrative: tbu
29-04-2019: IFOAM/FIBL (data driven IMS); banking sector, IMVO convenant, RSPO (living wage/ Anker method); Agriprofocus, media, ISEAL (gender approach)

29-04-2020: 1) Companies promote/request a requirement for child labor remediation & shared investment in CL remediation during ICI board meeting 2) Companies / supply chain actors support and promote the new Assess and Address Approach (as opposed to zero tolerance) 3) The European Commission published their communication on Deforestation ( July 24) which includes legistlative measures and a platform that RA supports. The discussion on EU level was whether or not to have legislation as part of the way forward on deforestation, i.e. mandatory measures in the mix of policies to combat deforestation; 4) The Dutch government changed their position towards including legistlation (mandatory measures) in the way forward on deforestation, which influenced the decision at EU level. 5) IDH also published a position supporting regulations in the way forward on deforestation on EU level ; 6) CFI is working on a definition of agrofrestry and they are referencing/collaborating with RA. 7) European Cocoa Association event statement included position on due diligence, in line with RA position on the panel 8) during the living wage conference co-organized by RA, several companies made specific commitments to contribute to a living wage 9) in discussions on how to improve incomes the Gha/ cdi government mentioned our living income benchmark.

title.narrative: DD3 # of requests received by UTZ and partners from different stakeholders (governments, companies, CSOs, etc) to provide input for policy making

description.narrative: Stakeholders ask and use UTZ knowledge, experience, tools for policy development and implementation (incl sourcing practices)

comment.narrative: tbu.
29-04-2019: ICI, Mars (CL), Dutch Gov (cocoa strategy, LW), GCP, CIAT, EU cocoa NGO coalition, 3 cocoa companies (deforestation); ICTSD; ICO, ISEAL (gender); GISCO NGO subgroup

29-04-2020: 1) RA is on the working group on HR due diligence at the ministry 2) EU ( DG-trade and DG Devco) ask/receive input through meetings from RA for policy design on child labor in international supply chains. 3) RA is in the board of the GISCO steering committee, 4) RA is member of the Beyond Chocolate initiative and provided input on the monitoring framework 5) GCP: RA staff think along at the GCP Congress and engages in discussions and brainstorms on the way forward and general concepts and give input to the GCP Global Coffee Standard 6) RA partcipated in the roadmap and the consultation for the EU deforestation policy. Meeting with EC. Cocoa and deforestation event organized by IDH, Tropenbos and RA (as one of the side meetings of the Amsterdam Declaration Partnership meeting in June) brought actors together to have this discussion 7)GISCO adopted new goals and included one on deforestation and one on agroforestry. The GISCO secretariat asked us for our definition of agroforestry and the GISCO -NGO group asked us to propose a GISCO agroforestry objective. 8) companies discuss policies and collaboration on deforestation and CC with RA and endorse the RA standard 9) ISEAL Gender Workgroup have asked us to co-organize 2 webinars around gender in new RA standard, 10. gender expert group of Dutch CSO's have asked RA to organize a session and share our tools

title.narrative: # and type of structural collaborations with gov., private sector, other standards, CSOs etc.

comment.narrative: N/A
18-07-2019: GCP; Conservation International; NGO cocoa coalition (EU), WO=MEN

29-04-2020: 1) joint advocacy activities on CL together with NGO partners including ICI, Fairtrade and the Voice network 2) GCP congress Basel: different country platform coordinators GCP faciliate discussions and exchange learnings 3) Collaboration with Conservation International put deforestation higher on the agenda in the coffee sector 4) Dutch CSO's have formed a gender expert group, and asked RA to organize a session / share our tools 5) WO=MEN have asked for a meeting to discuss continuation of collaboration beyond SP 6) Together with partners, RA co-organized a living wage conference ('the only way is up'); this conference connected the Dutch LW community to the German LW community around GIZ and strengthened collaboration between the Dutch and German govt 7) several standard organizations have joined the GLWC 8) increased membership of the Living Income Community of Practice

29-04-2021: 1. With over 100 other NGOs, we joined the #together4forests campaign organized by WWF and Greenpeace. The campaign helps individual people to submit pre-defined answers defined by a coalition of NGOs to the EU consultation. 2 We have launched ALIGN together with Fairfood and Hivos, an interactive tool that walks companies through an action process for achieving living wages in their supply chains.

title.narrative: DD3 # and type of panel discussions/ speaking opportunies

comment.narrative: N/A
18-07-2019: Global Landscapes Forum, AFCA, SCA, GCP

29-04-2020: 1) Conference on tackling child labour 2) GCP Country Congress Basel CH 3) Cocoa and deforestation event (side meeting of the Amsterdam Declaration Partnership meeting in June 2019) 4)ECA (European Cocoa Association) forum 2019, Lisbon; RA was on a panel 5) GIZ focused on agroforestry in their annual conference and gave space for RA to showcase our approach 6) Living wage conference (the only way is up) organized with partners

these targets have been corrected to align with the new/additional reporting guidelines
17-04-2018: Child labor risk assessment tool, Gender capacity strengthening, Living Wage benchmarking (internal project), Deforestation task force (internal project)
these targets have been corrected to align with the new/additional reporting guidelines
29-04-2019: child labor knowledge guide

29-04-2021: 1. Elaboration of training modules for gender related issues for different target groups, that are building on the experiences that have been gathered in the scope of the Sector Partnership Program. 2.Updating the Child Labor Knowledge Guide to update references to the new Rainforest Alliance Standard requirements and incorporate feedback from the International Cocoa Initiative, market partners and Rainforest Alliance experts,

title.narrative: Pathway 4: Support/strenghten MSPs, coalitions, networks, umbrella organizations
DD3 # of MSP's, coalitions, networks & umbrella organizations formed or strengthened

description.narrative: MSPs, coalitions, networks & umbrella organizations formed / with increased capacities & space for participation

comment.narrative: tbu
29-04-2019: GCP; VOICE, GLWC
Target value for this period has not been defined yet.

title.narrative: # of joint statements issued/publications produced/agreements made

description.narrative: MSPs/coalitions/networks engage in L&A for issue;

comment.narrative: tbu
29-04-2019: Due dilligence guidance document (ISEAL)

29-04-2020: 1) All GISCO members agreed to the goal to eradicate child labour for all chocolate on the German market by 2030 and in included in the monitoring framework SMART objectives to ac hieve this 2) Beyond Chocolate has developed a monitoring framework with indicators to measure the progress on stopping child labour for cocoa on the Belgian market 3) GISCO adopted new goals and included one on deforestation and one on agroforestry. 4) GISCO adopted new goals, of which one (nr. 7) is on enhancing gender equality, and also they developed a monitoring framework in which indicators on gender equality are incorporated. 5) Eurapean Cocoa Association event/statement on due dilligence in line with our position (we were on the panel which took place in September 2019) 6) We sent a letter with the Dutch Forest Coalition (coalition with WWF, Greenpeace, Solidaridad, IUCN, Tropenbos).

title.narrative: # of collaborative actions of CSOs with gov., private sector, other CSOs and MSPs

description.narrative: MSPs/coalitions/networks engage in L&A for issue;

comment.narrative: Target values for outcomes are currently being evaluated and will be updated.
29-04-2019: NGO cocoa coalition

29-04-2020: 1) country coffee platforms exchanged learnings during the GCP Country Congress in Basel CH 2) GISCO agreed on new goals and developed a monitoring framework 3) Beyond Chocolate has developed a monitoring framework with indicators to measure the progress on stopping child labour for cocoa on the Belgian market 4) The existing 3 European Cocoa Platforms, Swissco, GISCO and Beyond Chocolate (And the one in development, DISCO) developed a common indicator framework, to make sure the work is not doubled. It includes common indicators for child labour, deforestation and agroforestry.

title.narrative: DD3 # of sector platforms including issues proposed by UTZ and/or partners on the agenda

description.narrative: MSPs/coalitions/networks include issues in their agenda

comment.narrative: tbu
29-04-2019: GCP (economic viability of famers; pricing, climate); AFCA screened the Child Labor Documentary; SCA (deforestation)
Target value for this period has not been defined yet.

29-04-2020: 1) GCP Sustainability topics are put on the agenda or updated, through the National Sustainability Curriculum; plus GCP country congress Basel) 2) GISCO included RA priority issues in their goals 3) Beyond Chocolate included RA's input in the monitoring framework 4) Sustainable Coffee Challenge put deforestation higher on the agenda 5) AFCA- WCR shared material from SP project about coffee varieties [and many topic on the agenda during sustainability day!] 6) ISEAL- They have asked us to co-organize 2 webinars around gender in new RA standard, 7) GLWC 8) World Banana Forum (use of Anker methodology)
